title: Will the winner of the popular vote in the US presidential election also win the electoral college?
preds:
Hillary Clinton won the popular vote, but lost the electoral college. A statistically improbable fluke. Mrs Clinton may not have won the majority of electoral votes, but more Americans across the nation voted for her than voted for Mr Trump, according to the latest count. It doesn't look like a big difference but if the vote were conducted on a national level, Mrs Clinton would have won by a margin of more than 200,000 votes. The electoral map looks like a sea of red as it stands, but this is because Democrats tend to win more densely populated, delegate-rich states, while Republicans win geographically larger, less populous states. http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-10/us-election-was-closer-than-you-think/8012392
http://www.euronews.com/2016/11/10/hillary-clinton-loses-presidential-election-but-wins-the-popular-vote
The vote count differential has been trending upward since I've been paying attention to it. https://g.co/kgs/yJ5b1C
swing/miss.  Clinton really ran up the score in CA.   +2.5 million over Trump.
As of now Clinton is up about 200,000 votes, with 92% of votes counted.

This election is a disaster for the forecasting community and I mean a whole host of professionals, not just GJO. Most probably for a time money, if any, will dry out for this project. Hopefully, it will run on just enthusiasm of its founders.
No idea why they let us update these after the fact.  Looks like HRC will get popular, DJT electoral

http://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/president
Democrats look likely to win the popular vote. Edit: @nrohr Just wanted to say that you folks may not be right to keep this one still open for forecasting, since the event of voting is already in the past. Only the counting is not over as of now and that is not sufficient reason to keep this question open.

It looks like HRC will lose the EC vote but win the popular vote.
http://www.nytimes.com/elections/forecast/president

Early results from Dixville Notch, New Hampshire:
HRC...............4
DT.................2
GJohnson.....1
MRomney....1
http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/08/politics/dixville-notch-results-2016/index.html

Today's stock market rise and dollar strength appear to forecast an HRC win:
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-stocks-idUSKBN1321FT?il=0 DJIA up 2%+
Vix (fear gauge) down 17%
Mx Peso up.
US dollar up
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
I believe Secretary Clinton will win the popular vote relatively narrowly (about 3 pct points), just enough to head off the chances of a loss in the electoral college.

Polls are close but EV counts are not. 
http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/11/03/why-electoral-college-landslides-are-easier-to-win-than-popular-vote-ones/

HRC carries higher density states by a wider margin than trump does overall. But the polls are likely underestimating how mad the middle class is at the political elite. it's all about turnout. DJT wins EC at 270 to 268, but losses PV by about 1%.
DT popular + EC seems unlikely even if he wins popular. So, how likely is HC to win popular?
Secretary Clinton is strongly favored to win the electoral college vote, and she is also likely to win the popular vote.
HRC could win with less then a majority of the popular vote.   But if Trump wins, I would expect him to also win the popular vote
Clinton has support in states with more electoral college votes, so I wouldn't be all that surprised if she gets a minority of the popular vote but gets to 270 anyway.
Maine is the state that could tip this with DJT winning a portion of the electoral votes in this state.
I am predicting that Clinton will win the electoral college and she currently has a slight edge in the national polls.  I expect it to hold if not grow.
It's going down to the wire. You can't lose by underestimating the intelligence of the average voter.
538 has this at 88% as of now
As of right now I think that the odds of that happening are slim.
Down 10% for scoring purposes since I've been close to 100% the entire question. Shifting sands, perhaps. http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/366782
Nate Silver now forecasting a one in 10 chance that the wins could be split. Close watch on polling trends, but one week out I'm happy to drop 3% in case a couple of key states swing late.

"The Odds Of An Electoral College-Popular Vote Split Are Increasing 
Thus, as of early Monday evening, our polls-only model gave Hillary Clinton an 85 percent chance of winning the popular vote but just a 75 percent chance of winning the Electoral College. There’s roughly a 10 percent chance of Trump’s winning the White House while losing the popular vote, in other words." http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-odds-of-an-electoral-college-popular-vote-split-are-increasing/?ex_cid=538fb I do not want to overreact, but I still went down at least a tiny bit as a result to this.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Let's see:
1. It is not completely impossible, even though the more populous states of CA, NY, IL, PE will certainly vote Clinton. In 2012 Romney won only 38% of the electoral vote, but 48% of the popular vote which goes against the logic in the first sentence. 
2. I don't believe Clinton will win by a lot in the electoral vote or the popular vote; she will certainly win the first as she is pulling key battleground states and for the second: I am skeptical of more than 2/5 of women, and more than 1/2 of men to give their vote for Trump
All the polls indicate 5% lead for Clinton. The polls also indicate Clinton winning most of the battleground state. This leaves no room for a mis-match.
Trump may wind up a minority president if he wins.

It appears Clinton has the lead in both the popular vote and the electoral college. Although I live in a very red state with Trump signs everywhere I turn, I see no way that Trump will carry the day, either in the popular vote of the electoral college.
Polls showing large lead for Clinton in electoral college and higher population count in those states with some landslide victories
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Only one time in recent history (2000) this was not the case.
Adjusted for pkempf's point on how rarely this has not happened in the past.

It is rare for the popular vote winner not to win the electoral college, and the system is (thankfully) set up in such a way that it is only likely to happen in a relatively close race. This race is not close.
I certainly hope so, or we are seriously in trouble.
Clinton looks the likely winner of the electoral race, and she is strongest in states with the largest populations.
Highly likely. Clinton is playing the same Electoral game Obama played 8 years ago.

Pending any extensive changes in the next debate and the likely slew of additional bad press targeting the two major parties that is likely forthcoming in the next few week, the counts are still likely there.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Raising from 88% to 97% after Trump's troubles.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Clinton is consistently doing well on the national polls, but the same polls (summarized at 5-30-8) tell us that if Trump flips either Colorado or New Hampshire, he will win the electoral college.
Dropping from 88% to 80%. Side note: My probability of overall Trump victory is at 25% as of now.
Turn out will likely be high so likely alignment between electoral/popular.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/#plus 538 has a 7.7% chance of Clinton losing the electoral college while winning the popular vote, along with a 1.6% chance of Trump doing the same.

Outside chance that white voters in swing states could toss the election to Trump while minority voters will be overrepresented in noncompetitive states.  I'm still waiting for the debates and the media coverage following.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Dropping 3% to be just under the consensus. Nothing related to this US election makes any sense.
going down slightly; there are a few scenarios in which Trump just scrapes this
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

A few polls show Trump with the national lead in the vote count.  State polls all seem to favor HRC on the total vote count. Discounting the 3rd party candidates as a factor in the electorial college, as it seem very unlikely that the candidates will win any states.
it will be a blow out in both popular and electoral college
While 4 presidents have been elected without winning the popular vote, only 1 instance of this has occurred since 1888, making it extremely unlikely that it will occur this year.

The race might be surprisingly close.  However, while the Republican might actually win the popular vote, most of his votes are concentrated in farm belt and Rocky Mountain states, and this will distort the electoral college.  Hence, Trump could win the popular vote by as much as 2%, he could still lose in the electoral college.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The way the voting system is set up is that the people do not vote directly for candidates, instead they vote to determine what party will get the most electoral votes. Therefore, the electoral college has all the power.
Since it looks like Clinton will win the general, yes. But if Trump goes into the lead, probably not.

The question itself states only 4 times[2] presidents have been elected without wining the popular vote. There have been 58 elections in total[1]. There is a 6.8965% chance of happening based on past history. Inverse of that is 93.1%. HC however has a decisive edge on DT in both electoral[3] and popular vote[4]. The already remote possibility is close to zero currently. This race isn't that close. [1]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election
[2]http://www.factcheck.org/2008/03/presidents-winning-without-popular-vote/
[3]http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2016/08/latest_odds_on_hillary_clinton.html
[4]http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/us-presidential-elections-2016-poll-tracker-latest-donald-trump/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

I consider this a virtual certainty, given two conditions.  One is that I am predicting a high probability of Clinton being elected president.  The other is that a democratic candidate would be much more likely to experience a situation where he / she wins the popular vote, but loses in electoral votes.  This dynamic (which I believe will become more pronounced in the future) is because many of the states dominated by democrats have very high population concentrations.  Not so much in the middle of the country.   Anyway, even if Trump won (looking pretty improbable), the condition in question would be unlikely.  It would somehow have to be a close vote, with just the right configuration of winning and losing states.  All this rarely happens, even when a republican wins.   538 wrote a piece on all this, which has a bit of a different take.  But comes to about the same conclusion.  
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dont-worry-about-the-electoral-college-math/ Now if we see Trump pull in VERY close to Clinton and stay there, I will reduce probability.

I consider this a virtual certainty, given two conditions.  One is that I am predicting a high probability of Clinton being elected president.  The other is that a democratic candidate would be much more likely to experience a situation where he / she wins the popular vote, but loses in electoral votes.  This dynamic (which I believe will become more pronounced in the future) is because many of the states dominated by democrats have very high population concentrations.  Not so much in the middle of the country.   Anyway, even if Trump won (looking pretty improbable), the condition in question would be unlikely.  It would somehow have to be a close vote, with just the right configuration of winning and losing states.  All this rarely happens, even when a republican wins.   538 wrote a piece on all this, which has a bit of a different take.  But comes to about the same conclusion.

Fivethirtyeight currently has the combined chances of either candidate winning the popular vote winning the electoral college at 4.0%. While Trump's recent uptick in national polls increases his chances at the popular vote, it is likely only an incremental chance not worth a full percentage point

It will not be close either way.  Whoever wins will blow out the other.  They both have highly unlikeable traits, and it will come down to who savages the other most effectively.

If HRC wins, she will face accusations of being a chest and The Trump camp will challenge it vehemently.
If Trump does it, then HRC will challenge the result, ad it seems now.

Clinton will sweep this cycle unless a super bomb drops before the election.
Donald Trump has demographics skewing away from him.
If it happens likely only trump and it's pretty unlikely he will win combined with the fact that even if that happens unlikely he loses vote but wins electoral college.

With the entry of a Libertarian candidate and a Green candidate into the race, each of whom will pull votes from both the main candidates - it becomes more likely that the victor will pull the most electoral college votes, but fail to take a majority in the popular vote.

The only way this might happen is if Trump withdraws, which seems increasingly likely, and Clinton's campaign falters.  So could happen with a Ryan vs Clinton race.
Election is less likely to be close, so Electoral College votes should correlate more closely with the popular vote

Up 3% until something in the polling changes significantly.
The marginal voter will either veer away from Trump or not vote at all.
Up 10% to be at the consensus until something in the polls suggests a(n even) strange(r) year.

Sometimes, it is in-congruent when you look at multiple individual forecasts of your own - together! It is almost given that if Hillary wins the general election, she will win the popular vote as well. I have Trump at 33% for winning the election; But i think the odds of him winning the popular vote is 10%. So the odds of him winning the electoral college but not the popular vote should be 23%. Making the odds for this question to be 77%. That seems very high! To keep the odds of same person winning the electoral college and the popular vote at 93% and the odds of Trump winning the election at 33%, one has to believe Trump has 26% chance of winning popular vote. Something has to give! But for now, just like the American public, I am going to leave the choices bewildering.  p.s.: American public has 90+% un-favorability ratings for Congress, yet re-elects >80% of incumbents!!!

4 of 44 elections have gone this way, if you count 2000. So we have historical precedent (three 19th century instances) versus recency bias (Gore 2000) where 3rd party Nader was a spoiler enough to cause the Supreme Court to weigh in.  So let's call it 40.5/44, or 92% baseline chance.  The spoilers this year are offset by the fact that they draw from Trump at this point, which in winner take all states helps the leader in the current popular vote polling.  Current Supreme Court won't decide an election that way again, so add 1% for that.  I'm going with 93% at the moment.
Super majorities in blue states and red state voters staying home will insure the blue state ev count will match the popular vote majority.

There is conflict within the republican party officials more so than the democratic party. The only way this wouldn't play out is if Trump wins the popular vote. Among the electoral college, they would normally vote on behalf of the popular vote of their state. However there is the chance that they go against the wishes of the majority of their state, and in this particular election this chance is high. I believe the net betrayals will be in Clintons favor, since she has a less fragmented party behind her.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/#plus "Clinton wins popular vote but loses Electoral College	6.1%
Trump wins popular vote but loses Electoral College	2.1%"
The race is starting to look closer, and the closer the race, the more likely a popular vote will diverge from the electoral college.

If Trump wins, he may do so by losing the popular vote.  Most blue states will go hard for Hillary.  Trump will not do as well as Bush or Romney in Red states (leakage to Libertarian party).   Trump's margin in the swing states (PA, OH, IA, WI, NC, FL) will be small.  Effectively, Hil's margin of victory in the blue states will be greater than Trump's in the red states and the swing states will be close, so Trump will lose the popular vote (even if he wins the electoral college).    If you think this scenario is a 50/50 condition chance (i.e. IF Trump wins, he has a 50 percent chance of doing so while losing the popular vote), you take your probability of  Trump winning the election, halve it and subtract that from 100 to determine the probability for this response
I think HRC wins, and maybe narrowly in the electoral college, but will have  big popular vote win in large blue states.

We have seen several presidential elections where a candidate won the electoral college but lost the popular vote. The reverse is highly unlikely. It would require high percentage vote totals in just the right combination of states with lower electoral college votes.
Rank and file voters are polarized, Electoral College may feel obligated to make the "correct decision".

Based on history, the odds are probably about 98% that same candidate will win both popular vote and electoral college.  In the last 5 out 6 elections democrats got the higher popular vote. If Hillary wins the election, she will definitely get more popular vote.  Trump could win electoral college without winning popular vote. I am estimating Trump's chances at 40% right now to win the electoral college. He is likely to win if there is a major terrorist attack on USA before the election. If that happens, he is likely to win the popular vote as well. I am putting odds of him winning the popular vote at 33%.  So there is a 7% chance it can be split. So the chances of split vote is remote.
Highly likely. But first term elections were more contested than second term elections.

In my opinion, this is a much trickier question than it at first appears. Keep in mind that I'm using the 2012 popular vote totals as a benchmark. As I've said elsewhere, if Trump gets 5% more of the white vote that Romney got, he wins even if he loses 10%+ of the Hispanic vote that Romney got. I think Trump will carry most of the Rust Belt, in addition to the states that Romney carried. But it's a matter of distribution. Trump can get very small majorities in the states he turns from Democratic to Republican for this election, but at the same time do very poorly among Hispanic voters in states he has no hope of winning, like California and New Jersey. Trump would still win Texas even if he loses a significant percentage of the Hispanic vote there, but that loss would mean that his national popular vote total would be lower. In other words, he may squeak by to victories in some swing states, and win in states he is expected to carry, albeit with smaller totals, but get utterly clobbered in states where you would expect him to lose anyway. But those minuscule margins in swing states and lower totals in safe Republican states would put him over 270. In fact, I think he could win by a significant electoral margin, and still lose the popular vote by a fraction of a percent. I don't think any of this applies to Clinton. If she wins, it will be with a popular vote majority.

given that 7% of all presidential elections had a winner without the popular vote & how close the vote is in certain swing states, I have given a few more points to the off-chance that the winner wont be most popular.
Down 3% to match consensus. Beginning to wonder whether DT will have a HUGE popular vote in red states that might tilt the popular vote in his favor even if HRC ekes out an electoral college win.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Donald Trump possesses the one thing Hillary Clinton does not. A perception of genuineness. That will draw many more people to vote that previously did not. Hillary however, knows how to ensure the electoral math works. She will win.
I dont expect either the popular or electoral results to be very close.

Given the polarized views of the candidates of this election I feel turn out will be good if for no other reason to stop the other candidate, I think the numbers will be reflected well with the electoral college.

It's very rare for this to not happen, and it won't be a close race no matter which way it goes.

At this point I am predicting a landslide win for Hillary Clinton, with her taking both the popular and EC votes by historic margins.  My bet is that sanity will in the end prevail.  I hope that turns out to be true.
Neither candidate has a peculiar geographic appeal that would alter the general mathematics of the race. Thus, only a bizarre outcome could account for a split decision.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Trump will fade fast and RNC will shift support to down ballot. Dems will walk away with White House.
Three presidents elected without winning the popular vote since the end of the Civil War. Thirty-seven elections since the end of the Civil War. So, that's a base rate of 92%
More states will turn blue in the wake of Trumps comments. He will inevitably shoot himself in the foot at some point.
The political situation is really polarized. A Victory for any candidate will mean a clear victory in both, popular and electoral votes.

This has only happened 4 times in history out of I believe 57 elections and only once since 1888. That's about a 7% rate historically, I'm adjusting it down a bit though as I don't believe this election is going to be particularly close.
History (rare for a 2000 election event).  Also, I believe this one is going to be a "landslide" for one or the other.
"President" Al Gore knows about sure things.
4 out of 57 prior elections historically provide a baserate... but I suspect all 4 were close races. As this is currently a 77/23 odds favoring Hillary, I adjusted up the baserate from 93 to 96%.
Popular has won 52 out of 56 presidential elections 92%
at a time of revolt against the elite, challenging the "voice of the people" would be dangerous - no elector will dare to change side
Right now, it isn't looking like the race will be that close. But we'll have more to go on after the conventions.
This election will likely be different than historical trends, but I think the results of both processes will result in the same winner.

There have been 56 elections. In 3 of the elections (1876, 1888 and 2000), the candidate who won an absolute majority of the electoral college hadn't won the popular vote. In 1824, no candidate won an absolute majority in the electoral college and the House decided the election. So, in 52 of the 56 elections, the winner of the popular vote also won the electoral college. This is a base rate of 93%.

56 Presidential Elections
  4 lost popular vote but won electoral college.
Equals 92.8% success rate.
  subtract 1 (Adams vs. Jackson which was decided in the House
Now equals 94.5% success rate
  subtact 1 Rutherford Hayes won by 1 electoral vote in the Compromise of 1877, even though he started 19 electoral votes behind and lost popular vote by 250K
Now the popular vote winner wins  96.2% of the time
If you thrown out Bush v. Gore (Gore won the popular vote) this goes up to 98.1% of the time.
The external view is this event will happen 98.1% of the time
Through in tip of the nose revulsion for Donald Trump and I am at 99%
I think that neither of the candidates are very popular this election, and I don't think the election will be very close.

If Hillary wins i think we can all agree it will be by a large enough margin. I have the odds of her winning 40% (i dislike Trump immensely but that isn't relevant as many learned from Brexit). If Trump wins i also think it will be by a large enough margin. The base rate here is well over 90%. Any Trump victory will be because of a huge turnout among his closet voters, so that cinches it for me.

Only 4 presidents have won the electoral college without winning the popular vote. Current polls (and the betting market) indicate that Hillary Clinton 75% to 85% of winning (the electoral college), suggesting that she is likely to win the popular vote as well.

If Trump wins (which I think is about a 25 percent probability)  he will likely do so while losing the popular vote.  In the safe red states he will win, his vote total will be hurt by the Libertarian vote, and in safe blue states he will be trounced handily.   His best chance is to edge out Clinton in the rust belt and Florida.
The total US history of voting pegs this at 4/43, or 91% of occurrence. However, modern US history post 1888 pegs this at a 95% chance of occurrence. I take a blend of the two approaches.
according to 538, this is a 4% probability event. I'll take their word for it
The popular vote result and the electoral college only differ in close elections and I expect Trump to lose heavily.

I'm a bit concerned that popular votes might be very high in certain states (*cough* California *cough*) but not representative of the wider electoral college. States are usually winner-take-all, so 70% in a state is no more votes than 50.1%, but the 70% would skew the popular vote in a way that the wider electoral college would not represent. Skewed votes seems extra likely this election.

I believe either Hillary or Trump will win this race in a landslide. Probably Hillary, but could also be Trump. Either way, it is not likely to be close, so I think the electoral and popular votes wlll agree.
Yes since it will be Hilary

Last time this happens was Bush '00. Since then there has been three elections and electoral and popular did not diverge. However, the last three elections were not close either. The only other time electoral and popular vote diverges were 1888, 1876 and 1824. 
Given that at this point Hillary is mostly locked in to win, and to win the big states too, there is no chance that we are going to see electoral and popular diverge.
But I'd have to adjust this if polls start showing a closer race, or if Hillary did not make it to be a candidate, or Republican has another candidate other than Trump.
The larger states with the most electors should dominate the next election.  This should push the popular vote into being inline with the electoral college.
It will be a landside victory for Clinton. I predict she will win even Florida!
minority voters will overwhelmingly vote democrat
Clinton will carry all the 5 largest states except Texas
The margins look to be quite high (according to polls). It is difficult to see a path where the electoral college and popular vote are different.

There have been 57 prior US presidential elections: http://www.270towin.com/historical-presidential-elections/ According to the question description, four of those elections were won without the popular vote. I personally do not claim to have very substantial knowledge that would shift the posterior up or down, so I will go with the prior: 53/57 or about 93%.
This is not sizing up like Bush v Gore or Hayes-Tilden

I plan to keep following 538 from now on.

no clue.

When I first read the Q, I had to do a "double take" as it seemed so obvious based on historical outcomes. That said, Prof. Kahneman came to mind on his recent thinking fast & slow publication. The easy & fast  answer will of course, be the winner of the popular vote wins the electoral college vote. On the other hand, political pollsters, well known so called experts in this area &, the punditry have been proven wrong time and again. Indeed, it looks absolutely ugly "no chance" saloon for DT at this stage and, punditry is again "DOUBLING DOWN" on its original false meme in spite of the actual outcome voted upon by those actually going to the poll to vote. 79% probability says Silver, again! Sound familiar ?http://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/nate-silver-who-will-be-president-prediction-224931 NB: BREXIT, Trump & Sanders phenomenon.  It has therefore "paid" to seriously consider, on second thought, a more nuanced, out of the box, probability of an event that has NOT happened or, if so, an anomaly to a standard diviation over the past 100 years! It is ALWAYS what NEVER happened before, that has the biggest impact! Just ask Remain campaigners, the standard bearer GOP elite status quo and, HRC supporters on how & how Sanders is still around.
So, this Q from my perspective has an interesting participation opportunity. I'm in but, will start w/ the easy answer.
al gore won pop vote. but this is different.

(no change) Mostly as a reminder to me (and I believe others may have discussed this). I'm making two assumptions regarding the question. 1. Winning the popular vote means the candidate with the largest number of votes, which will possibly be only a plurality. 2. Winning the electoral college means the EC will elect someone with a majority of the votes. Anything else (goes to the House by whatever path, etc.) won't count.

Sneaky question..."Win" has two different meanings in this question.
"Win the popular vote" generally means, the candidate with the most popular votes, regardless of what percentage of the total that may represent.
"Win the electorial college" requires winning more than 50% of the electorial vote.
Per the expanded question, GBush "having been elected" actually required winning more than 50% of the ec votes, not simply collecting more than the next candidate. Two possibilities?:
....HRC wins the popular vote, with strong results in Dem states, while Trump (TBD??) wins the electorial college with narrow margins in more states.
....A strong third party (or third, fourth and fifth...GOP, lib, etc.) candidate (s), resulting from dissatisfied voters, could prevents any one candidate from exceeding the 50% electorial college mark, And create an unusual outcome.  This includes the discarded(?) GOP option to split the vote, in an attempt to move the selection of the president to the House.

Given that it has only happened 4 times. "The 2000 election was the most recent when the candidate who received the greatest number of electoral votes, and thus won the presidency, didn’t win the popular vote. But this scenario has played out in our nation’s history before. In 1824, John Quincy Adams was elected president despite not winning either the popular vote or the electoral vote. Andrew Jackson was the winner in both categories. Jackson received 38,000 more popular votes than Adams, and beat him in the electoral vote 99 to 84. Despite his victories, Jackson didn’t reach the majority 131 votes needed in the Electoral College to be declared president. In fact, neither candidate did. The decision went to the House of Representatives, which voted Adams into the White House. In 1876, Rutherford B. Hayes won the election (by a margin of one electoral vote), but he lost the popular vote by more than 250,000 ballots to Samuel J. Tilden. In 1888, Benjamin Harrison received 233 electoral votes to Grover Cleveland’s 168, winning the presidency. But Harrison lost the popular vote by more than 90,000 votes. In 2000, George W. Bush was declared the winner of the general election and became the 43rd president, but he didn’t win the popular vote either. Al Gore holds that distinction, garnering about 540,000 more votes than Bush. However, Bush won the electoral vote, 271 to 266. "
http://www.factcheck.org/2008/03/presidents-winning-without-popular-vote/

Historically only 4 Presidential elections were split (out of 57), but only 1 of the past 32 elections were split (since 1888), so the base rate is between 7 and 3%. I'll call it 4% since 3 of the 4 split elections in all of history were before 1888 - it seems there's been a structural change to make them less likely.
This year continues 8 years of massive under investment by Republicans in data, meaning they're likely to under perform in the electoral college relative to their popular vote. Meanwhile the Democrats have ramped up 8 years of massive investment in electoral data so are likely to over perform electorally relative to the popular vote. This makes a split outcome more likely if the popular vote is won by the Republicans and less likely if it is won by the Democrats.
Since I only give Trump about 20% chance to win the popular vote, I have to adjust down from the base rate of 4% to 1%. 
Recent polling gives Clinton a 5pt lead nationally, so that makes me comfortable despite the extreme prediction.
Normally I'd extremise to adjust for the way this prediction market works, but I don't like 100% predictions unless I believe the outcome is settled but not updated by GJO, so I wont extremise in this case.  A caveat: I'm not American and have spent about 10mins checking my facts, so if someone points out an error I may make a change.
